Enraute Hong Kong-Shanghai
July 10
1937
Dear Family:
I left Shanghai on Saturday, July 3, for an inspection
trip to Canton, Hong Kong, and Macao
with the new Managing Director
of CNAC, Colonel Lum Wei
Shing•
The Colonel was formerly a General
but along with dozens of others in the Chinese army, was reduced
in rank two years ago when the Chinese army was reorganized, and
they tried to give the title of General more significance than that
of Colonel in Kentucky•
title continues to
Ones usually affect some more face-giving rank such as Field Mar-
shal,
Air Marshal, and of course the topside Number One is
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-Shek.
We flew to Canton on Saturday and
spent July 4th there.
It was terribly hot and I was glad to
out to the International Club in the country for lunch.
There we
met several of the American pilots from Hangchon
who had flown
down to Canton also on an inspection trip with General Wong,
head
of the Chinese Air
Force.
Most of the Chinese top men in aviation
are graduates of american aviation schools and of
course all speak
English.
Spending the Fourth of July in Canton reminded me that
just four years ago we made the first commercial flight from Shanghai
down the coast.
lowing day.
he day in on bi a out on
on that occasion we also left Shanghai on July 3,
but spent the night at Foochow and continued our trip on the fol-
American,
On board our ship, four years ago,
we had a German-
Paul Groeger.
He is a good
sport and lots of fun, but
sometimes a bit slow on the trigger.
As we went in for a landing
at Amoy,
all ships in the harbor
were "dressed"
and all of course
flying
American flags in recognition of our independence day.
called out
nice
of
to Groeger who sat across
the aisle
from me,
"Pretty
them to
give us this
welcome"!
Groeger smiled
and nodded.
I think he secretly felt that we fully deserved the recognition.
The rest of
the day he went around stepping high with his chest well
out and a bit of swagger.
Finally he thanked someone for the wel-
come and discovered his
error.
around
to me and
said "Deese flags and decorations are not
George Washington's birthday"!
Well to return to my
story--in Canton there were no flags
and no firecrackers,
it was just the fourth day of
the seventh moon.
At five P. M. we took the Hong Kong Express and rode in the air-
conditioned car,
very popular this time of
the year.
It was a.
delightful three-hours
trip, but at the Hong Kong end the Number 8
typhoon signal was up--the wind shrieked, and rain came down in
sheets.
No use
trying a ricksha for the
coolies
could not pull them
against the wind or hold them back in running before it.
Finally
we
got a taxi
and made the hotel.
The following day the typhoon
had moved up the coast.
That evening I took a boat over to. Macao,
four hours by steamer.
Those Macao boats are always bad, but this
one was an awful
crate. It was commanded by Britishers--men who
